articles.name: Cloudflare Zero Trust Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.title: Cloudflare Zero Trust Integration Guide for SecurityCoach
articles.body:
In this article, you’ll learn how to integrate Cloudflare Zero Trust with SecurityCoach. Once the integration is complete, data provided by Cloudflare Zero Trust will be available for use under the SecurityCoach tab of your KSAT console. This data can be viewed in SecurityCoach reports and used to create real-time coaching campaigns. For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Set Up the Integration in Your Cloudflare Zero Trust Account

Before you can set up this integration in your KSAT console, you will need to create an API Token and copy your Account ID from your Cloudflare Zero Trust platform.

  1. Log in to your Cloudflare dashboard, then click My Profile from the navigation menu on the left side of the screen.
  2. Under the My Profile drop-down menu, click API Tokens > Create Token.
  3. Click Get started to create an API Token with custom permissions.
  4. In the Token name field, enter a name for your new token. Then, assign permissions as shown in the screenshot:
  5. Click Continue to summary. You will see a summary of the permission you’ve assigned to your API token. Ensure your permissions match the screenshot below:
  6. Click Create Token.
  7. Click Copy to copy your API Token. Make sure to save your copied API Token somewhere that you can easily access. You will need this token when you complete the integration in the Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console section below.
  8. Locate your Account ID in your Cloudflare dashboard. For example, in the image below, the Account ID is daa2f528f306548dcdd584886da4b318

Set Up the Integration in Your KSAT Console

Once you have created your API Token and copied your Account ID from your Cloudflare Zero Trust account, you can set up the integration in your KSAT console. To register Cloudflare Zero Trust in your KSAT console, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > Setup > Security Vendor Integrations.
  2. Locate Cloudflare Zero Trust and click Configure.
  3. Enter the API Token and Account ID that you saved in your Set Up the Integration in Your Cloudflare Zero Trust Account section of this article.
  4. Click Authorize.

Map Your Users

After you’ve finished integrating Cloudflare Zero Trust, you can map your users either through mapping rules (recommended) or through a CSV file upload. For more information about user mapping, see our Mapping Users in SecurityCoach article.

Once you’ve successfully authorized this integration, you can manage detection rules for Cloudflare Zero Trust on the Detection Rules subtab of SecurityCoach. For a full list of available system detection rules for this vendor, see our Which Detection Rules Can I Use with My Vendors? article.

articles.name: Integrate Cortex XSOAR with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.title: Integrate Cortex XSOAR with Your KnowBe4 Console
articles.body:
In this article, you can learn how to integrate Cortex's XSOAR platform with the KSAT console. Once you set up this integration, you'll be able to send your users' KSAT security awareness training and simulated phishing data to XSOAR. For example, you can use commands to send specific Risk Score or Phishing Security Test (PST) data. Then, you can use this data for your automations, playbooks, and reports in XSOAR. 

See the sections below to learn how to integrate XSOAR with KSAT. To learn about the benefits of integration, see our Cortex XSOAR and KnowBe4 document.

Configuring the Integration

To configure the integration, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your XSOAR account.
  2. Navigate to Settings > Integrations > Servers & Services.
  3. In the search bar at the top of the page, search for “KSAT”.
  4. Click Add instance to create and configure a new integration instance.
  5. Fill out the parameters with information about your KSAT console. For more information, see the table below:
    Parameter Description Requirement

    Instance Name

    Enter a name for your KSAT instance.

    Required

    Reporting Server URL

    Enter the Reporting Server URL for your KSAT instance, which you can find in our Reporting API documentation.

    Required

    Reporting API Key

    Enter the Reporting API key for the connection. To generate an API key, see our KSAT Account Settings: Account Integrations article.

    Required

    User Events Server URL

    Enter the User Event URL for your KSAT instance, which you can find in our User Event API documentation.

    Required

    User Events API Key

    Enter the User Event  API key for the connection. To generate an API key, see our User Event API article.

    Optional
  6. Click Test to validate the URLs, API keys, and connection.

Using Commands

After adding the integration, you can use commands to send data from KSAT to XSOAR. 

For a list of commands you can use, see the table below:

Command Description

kmsat-account-info-list

Use this command to send account information.

kmsat-account-risk-score-history-list

Use this command to send your organization's Risk Score history.

kmsat-groups-list

Use this command to send a list of your groups.

kmsat-groups-risk-score-history-list

Use this command to send Risk Score history for your groups.

kmsat-groups-members-list

Use this command to send groups and the users who are included in them.

kmsat-users-risk-score-history-list

Use this command to send the Risk Score history for your users.

kmsat-phishing-security-tests-list

Use this command to send all PSTs.

kmsat-phishing-security-tests-recipients-list

Use this command to send PSTs and user data for enrolled users.

kmsat-phishing-security-tests-failed-recipients-list

Use this command to send failed PSTs and user data for enrolled users.

kmsat-phishing-campaign-security-tests-list

Use this command to send PSTs from a specific phishing campaign.

kmsat-training-campaigns-list

Use this command to send all training campaigns.

kmsat-training-enrollments-list

Use this command to send all training enrollments.

kmsat-user-events-list

Use this command to send user events.

kmsat-user-event-types-list

Use this command to send the types of user events.

kmsat-user-event-create

Use this command to create an event on a user's User Timeline.

kmsat-user-event-delete

Use this command to delete an event from a user's User Timeline.

For more information, see Cortex XSOAR's KnowBe4 KSAT documentation.

articles.name: Customize SecurityTip Notification Templates
articles.title: Customize SecurityTip Notification Templates
articles.body:
KnowBe4 provides several built-in SecurityTip notification templates that you can use when you create real-time coaching campaigns. You can also create your own custom notification templates. SecurityTips are localized based on the recipient's training language.

For general information about SecurityCoach, see our SecurityCoach Product Manual.

Creating a Custom SecurityTip Notification Template

To learn how to create a custom SecurityTip notification template, follow the steps below:

  1. Log in to your KSAT console and navigate to SecurityCoach > SecurityTips > Notification Templates.
  2. Click + Create Notification Template at the top-right corner of the page.
  3. Fill out the fields on the New SecurityCoach Notification page. For more information about these fields, see below:

    1. Template Name: Enter a name for your template.
    2. Status: This drop-down menu defaults to Draft and cannot be changed until you save the template.
  4. Click Save. When you click, the Translations table will display.
  5. Click + Add Language to open the What You See Is What You Get (WYSIWYG) editor. For more information about the fields in this editor, see below:

    1. Language: Select a language for the translation. 
    2. Sender’s Email Address: Enter the email address that the SecurityTip email will appear to come from. You can use any email address you’d like.
    3. Sender’s Name: Enter the name that will appear next to the Sender’s Email Address when a user receives a SecurityTip by email.
    4. Subject: Enter a subject for the template. This subject will be visible to your users.
    5. Body: Enter any text that you’d like to display in the body of the template.
  6. Click Save to create the translation for this template.
  7. Optionally, repeat steps 5 through step 6 to add additional translations for the template.
  8. From the Status drop-down menu, select Active. Notification templates must be active for you to use them in a real-time coaching campaign.
  9. Click Save.

Managing and Editing SecurityTip Notification Templates

Once you have created a custom SecurityTip notification template, you can manage or edit the template at any time. To manage and edit your templates, navigate to SecurityCoach > SecurityTips > Notification Templates. You can find your existing templates under the My Templates section of the page.

Note:If you have used the template in an active real-time coaching campaign, you cannot delete or archive the template.

To learn more about the options available in the My Templates section, see below:

  1. My Templates: In this section, you can view a table that lists your custom templates. For each template, you can see the Language Count, Date Updated, and Status.
  2. Status: Select a status to filter templates by. You can choose from All, Active, Drafts, or Archived.
  3. Languages: Click this drop-down menu to filter content by language.
  4. Search: Search for a template by entering a keyword used in the template name.
  5. Template Name: Click a template name to edit that template.
  6. More Options: Click this icon to open a drop-down menu with more options, including the Clone and Delete buttons.
  7. Preview: Click this icon to preview the template.

articles.name: Smart Groups Gamification Automation Guide
articles.title: Smart Groups Gamification Automation Guide
articles.body:
In this article, you will learn how to use Smart Groups to gamify your security awareness program. Gamification can be applied to almost any user action, from completing training courses to reporting Phishing Security Tests (PSTs). We recommend using Smart Groups to identify users who have completed favorable actions, such as reporting two PSTs in one month.

For general information about creating Smart Groups, see our Smart Groups Quickstart Guide.

Step One: Plan the Rules of the Game

First, you’ll need to plan the rules of your game. This process is highly customizable, so we recommend using the questions below to plan your gamification process:

  1. What skills or actions do you want to target? For example, you could encourage users to report PSTs with the Phish Alert Button (PAB). Or, you could ask users to complete optional training by a certain date.
  2. How do you want to score the game? In other words, what defines success in your gamification process? For example, if a user reports three PSTs within a month, they have succeeded in the game.
  3. How long will this gamification process run? Determining a time frame will help you add accurate Smart Group criteria.

Gamification can be as simple or as complex as you would like. For example, you could create a simple game for reporting PSTs. To win this game, a user must report at least three PSTs in one month. Because this game only measures one type of action, you only need to create one Smart Group.

Or, you could make your game more complex. To win this game, users must earn 100 points in one month. Users earn 25 points for each PST they report and lose 25 points for each PST they fail. For this game, you would need a Smart Group for each combination of actions a user could take. For example, your Smart Groups could target the following combinations of actions:

Smart Group #1: Users who have reported four PSTs.

Smart Group #2: Users who have reported five PSTs and failed one PST.

Both of these combinations of actions add up to 100 points, so both groups include successful users. You can adjust the criteria for these groups based on how often you send PSTs to your users.

Step Two: Create Smart Groups for Your Game

Once you’ve planned your rules, you can create Smart Groups for your game. You will need to create Smart Groups for users who successfully complete your game as well as users who don’t successfully complete your game.

First, create a Smart Group to identify successful users. We recommend referencing our Smart Groups Glossary of Criteria Types to find the criteria that will work best for your group.

For example, if you want to create a game based on the simple example in the Step One: Plan the Rules of the Game section above, start by creating a Smart Group for successful users. We recommend naming this group something identifiable, such as “Successful Users”.

Then, add the following Phish Event criterion:

1. Condition: Select Must.
2. Phish Event: Select Reported.
3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
4. Count: Enter your desired number of reported phishing emails.
5. Time Frame: Select Range. Then, enter your desired start and end dates.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

Phish Event

User must have reported a phishing test greater than 2 times from 07/01/2022 through 08/01/2022.

Next, create one or more Smart Groups for users who did not succeed in your game. For example, if you’re following the simple game example from the Step One: Plan the Rules of the Game section above, your unsuccessful group should include any users who did not report any PSTs they received. We recommend naming this group something identifiable, such as “Unsuccessful Users”.

Then, add the following Phish Event criterion:

1. Condition: Select Must Not.
2. Phish Event: Select Reported.
3. Comparison: Select Greater Than.
4. Count: Enter your desired number of unreported phishing tests.
5. Time Frame: Select Range. Then, enter your desired start and end dates.

After you’ve filled out the fields listed above, click Save. Your finished criterion will state:

Phish Event

User must not have reported a phishing test greater than 0 times from 07/01/2022 through 08/01/2022.

Your game should target security awareness skills in your users, so anyone who doesn't win the game may need to improve their security knowledge. For example, if your game is focused on PST failures, you could enroll users in remedial training if they don’t succeed in your game.

Once you’ve created your Smart Groups, we recommend communicating the rules and timeline of your game with your users. Then, use the other features in your KSAT console, such as phishing or training, to start the game.

Step Three: Reward Successful Users

After your game ends, we recommend rewarding your successful users to encourage them to maintain their strong security awareness habits. For example, you could send a message to congratulate users for winning the game.

Tip: You can use our User Messaging feature to send a custom message to your successful Smart Group in the Learner Experience.

Once your game has ended, view your successful Smart Group to see the complete list of users. You can view this Smart Group by navigating to Users > Groups > and clicking on the name of the Smart Group. You can also export this information as a CSV file by clicking the Generate CSV button on the Smart Group’s overview page.

articles.name: How to Monitor Tasks from the View Control Page
articles.title: How to Monitor Tasks from the View Control Page
articles.body:
After you create tasks for your controls, you can monitor your tasks from the View Control page of your KCM GRC platform. To navigate to the View Control page, select the Controls tab from your navigation panel, and then select a control.

If you're looking for information about creating tasks, see our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article. 

See the subsections below to learn about how you can monitor your tasks from the subtabs of the View Control page. 

Recurring Tasks Subtab

From the Recurring Tasks subtab of the View Control page, you can view the recurring tasks that you've created. 

To learn about the columns on this subtab, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Schedule Name: View the name of the recurring task.  
  2. Frequency: View a description of how often tasks are created for the recurring task. 
  3. Current Due Date: View the due date of the current task. To open the task, click the date. If previous tasks have not been closed for this recurring task, this column will display the due date of the oldest task. If this field is blank and the task is a recurring task that uses Effective Date Range (EDR), the first task is not active in your account yet. For more information, see the When Do EDR Tasks Become Active? section of our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article. 
  4. Last Satisfied Date: View the date that the User Assigned most recently marked a task in the task as complete. To open the task, click the date. If this field is blank, the first task for the recurring task has not been completed.
  5. Last Approval Date: View the date that an approving manager most recently approved and closed the task. To open the task, click the date. This column will display N/A if an approving manager is not assigned to the task. For more information, see our How to Monitor and Approve Tasks article.
  6. EDR: If this column displays a check mark, the task uses Effective Date Range (EDR). For more information, see the Working with Tasks That Use EDR section of our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article. 
  7. Actions: If you would like to cancel the task, click the cancel icon in this column.

All Tasks Subtab

From the All Tasks subtab of the View Control page, you can view the one-time tasks that you have created. You can also view the most recent or upcoming tasks in the recurring tasks that you have created.

To learn about the columns on this page, see the screenshot and list below:

  1. Name: View the name of the task. You can also click the name to open the task.
  2. User Assigned: View the name of the user who is responsible for completing the task. 
  3. Approving Manager: View the name of the Approving Manager who is responsible for approving the task. For more information, see our Task Approval Workflow article.
  4. Schedule Frequency: View how often tasks will be created for the recurring task. If the task is a one-time task, this column will display One-Time Task. For more information, see the Task Frequencies section of our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article.
  5. Start Date: View the date that the task starts on. For more information, see the Task Frequencies section of our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article.
  6. End Date: View the date that the task ends on. For more information, see the Task Frequencies section of our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article.
  7. Due Date: View the date that the task is due on. For more information, see the Task Frequencies section of our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article.
  8. Status: View the current status of the task. For more information about the task statuses, see the list below: 
    • Active: The task is currently active in your account, and the task is not past due. For more information, see the Working with One-Time Tasks section of our How to Work with Tasks for Controls article.
    • Satisfied: The User Assigned has marked the task as complete. If the task does not require approval or has completed the approval process, this status indicates that the task is closed. 
      Note: Tasks that are currently waiting for approval from an approving manager may display a Satisfied status. You can see if a task is waiting for approval by viewing the Task Status section of the View Task page. For more information, see the Understanding Task Requirements section in our How to Monitor and Approve Tasks article.
    • Past Due: The task is between one and seven days past its due date.
      Note: By default, tasks will be in the Past Due status for seven days before the task's status changes to Failed. You can update the Task Fail Interval setting in your KCM GRC Account Settings to change the length of the Task Fail Interval. To learn how to update this setting, see the Task Fail Interval description in our How to Manage Your KCM GRC Account Settings article. 
    • Closed Late: The User Assigned marked the task as complete at least one day past the task's due date. This status can also mean that the task was closed one or more days past the task's due date because it was not approved until after the due date.  
      Note: Tasks that are currently waiting for approval from an approving manager may display a Closed Late status. To see if a task is waiting for approval, open the task and check the Task Status area. To learn more, see the Understanding Task Requirements section in our How to Monitor and Approve Tasks article.
    • Failed: The task has not been completed or closed, and the Task Fail Interval has passed. If the User Assigned marks the task as complete, the task's status will change to Closed Late.

articles.name: Holiday-Themed Cybersecurity Kit
articles.title: Holiday-Themed Cybersecurity Kit
articles.body:
The most wonderful time of the year can also be the most dangerous time of the year. Cybercriminals use the hustle and bustle of the holidays to catch users off guard. In preparation for the holiday season, we're providing two downloadable Security Hints and Tips newsletters as well as 10 new holiday-themed phishing templates. Read the sections below to learn more about these resources and how to use them.

For more holiday content, ask your Customer Success Manager or Account Manager for access to our 2024 KnowBe4 Holiday Kit.

Downloadable Security Hints and Tips Newsletters (PDFs)

We've created two holiday-themed Security Hints and Tips newsletters in a PDF format. These newsletters are based on two of the most popular ways cybercriminals target users during the holidays: shopping and travel scams.

Click the links below to download each newsletter in your preferred language.

November KnowBe4 Security Tips

Holiday Shopping

  • Chinese (Mandarin) - Simplified
  • English (Great Britain)
  • English (United States)
  • French (Canada)
  • French (Europe)
  • German
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Portuguese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Latin America)

December KnowBe4 Security Tips

Holiday Travel

  • Chinese (Mandarin) - Simplified
  • English (Great Britain)
  • English (United States)
  • French (Canada)
  • French (Europe)
  • German
  • Japanese
  • Korean
  • Portuguese (Brazil)
  • Spanish (Latin America)

New Holiday-Themed Phishing Templates and Landing Pages

We've created 10 new phishing templates for the holiday season. You can preview these templates by following the steps below:

  1. Navigate to the Phishing tab, then click on Email Templates.
  2. Click System Templates, then select Holiday from the System Categories list.
  3. Find the template you would like to preview and click the eye icon next to the template title. Alternatively, you can search for a template by name using the search bar. The new templates are listed below:
    • Airbnb: Create lasting memories this holiday season (Link)
    • Amazon: Give the gift of Prime this holiday season! (Link)
    • Apple: Holiday Promo: Get Apple Music Free Forever! (Link)
    • American Airlines: Celebrate the Holiday Season with American Airlines! (Link)
    • Holiday Travel with Company Devices Policy (Link) (Spoofs Domain)
    • Join Us for a Festive Card-Making Party! (Link) (Spoofs Domain)
    • Reminder: Update Your Calendar with Holiday PTO Plans (Link) (Spoofs Domain)
    • Stream your live holiday event with EventLive! (Link)
    • Ticketmaster: Holiday Concert Sweepstakes (Link)
    • Walmart: Complimentary Gift Wrapping this Holiday Season! (Link)

If you’re opted in to the Phishing Templates (Beta) feature, follow the steps below:

  1. Navigate to the Phishing tab, then click on Phishing Templates (Beta).
  2. Click System Templates.
  3. From the Topics drop-down menu, select Current Holiday.
  4. Find the template you would like to preview and click the eye icon next to the template title. Alternatively, you can search for a template by name using the search bar. The new templates are listed below:
    • Airbnb: Create lasting memories this holiday season (Link)
    • Amazon: Give the gift of Prime this holiday season! (Link)
    • Apple: Holiday Promo: Get Apple Music Free Forever! (Link)
    • American Airlines: Celebrate the Holiday Season with American Airlines! (Link)
    • Holiday Travel with Company Devices Policy (Link) (Spoofs Domain)
    • Join Us for a Festive Card-Making Party! (Link) (Spoofs Domain)
    • Reminder: Update Your Calendar with Holiday PTO Plans (Link) (Spoofs Domain)
    • Stream your live holiday event with EventLive! (Link)
    • Ticketmaster: Holiday Concert Sweepstakes (Link)
    • Walmart: Complimentary Gift Wrapping this Holiday Season! (Link)

To preview our holiday landing pages, follow the steps below:

  1. Navigate to the Phishing tab, then click on Landing Pages.
  2. Click System Landing Pages, then select Holiday/Seasonal from the System Categories list.
  3. Click on the eye icon next to the landing page you want to preview.

To learn how to create a campaign, see the How to Create a Holiday-Themed Phishing Campaign section below.

How to Create a Holiday-Themed Phishing Campaign

We recommend that you create multiple phishing campaigns to test your users throughout the holiday season. To create the phishing campaign, navigate to the Phishing tab of your KSAT console. Then, click + Create Phishing Campaign in the top-right corner of the page.

If you have the legacy version of phishing templates, follow the steps below. If you’re opted in to the Phishing Templates (Beta) feature, follow the steps in the Phishing Templates (Beta) Campaign subsection instead.

If you’d prefer to watch a video that explains how to set up a holiday-themed phishing campaign, check out our Create a Holiday-themed Phishing Campaign video.

Legacy Phishing Templates Campaign Instructions

On the New Phishing Campaign page, we recommend that you use the settings listed below:

  1. Campaign Name: Give the campaign a name, such as "Holiday-themed Phishing Campaign".
  2. Send to: Select All Users or select certain groups from the Specific Groups drop-down menu.
  3. Frequency: Select One-time.
  4. Start Time: Select your preferred date.
  5. Sending Period: We recommend that you send phishing emails over the course of three or more business days. 
  6. Template Categories: Select Holiday from the first drop-down menu and Full Random from the second drop-down menu.
  7. Landing Page: From the drop-down menu, select the landing page you would like to use.
  8. Once you are satisfied with your settings, click Create Campaign at the bottom of the page.

Phishing Templates (Beta) Campaign Instructions

On the New Phishing Campaign page, we recommend that you use the settings listed below: 

  1. Campaign Name: Give the campaign a name, such as "Holiday-themed Phishing Campaign".
  2. Send to: Select All Users or select certain groups from the Specific Groups drop-down menu.
  3. Frequency: Select One-time.
  4. Start Time: Select your preferred date.
  5. Sending Period: We recommend that you send phishing emails over the course of three or more business days. 
  6. Template Topics: Select Current Holiday from the first drop-down menu.
  7. Landing Page: From the drop-down menu, select the landing page you would like to use.
  8. Once you are satisfied with your settings, click Create Campaign at the bottom of the page.

articles.name: Grant Compliance Plus Access
articles.title: Grant Compliance Plus Access
articles.body:
Compliance Plus is a ModStore add-on option for current KnowBe4 customers with a KSAT subscription. Compliance Plus content gives your users the tools they need to help mitigate compliance risks.

Important: KnowBe4 requires that the number of seats purchased for Compliance Plus is the same number of seats purchased for KSAT. This includes purchasing additional seats throughout the subscription terms. Additional minimum subscription purchasing requirements may apply.

To be sure you are using the best content for your organization, work closely with your HR department and other compliance experts in your organization. We recommend setting up a security role that allows your compliance experts to search for Compliance Plus content as well as create and monitor compliance training campaigns. Once your compliance experts have access to the KnowBe4 console, they can use the article How Do I Use Compliance Plus Content? as a guide.

Creating User Groups for Compliance Training

For best results, we recommend creating two user groups:

  1. One group that only includes your compliance experts. 
    • This group will be used when assigning the security role.
  2. One group that only includes the users who should be enrolled in the compliance campaign. Be sure to name it something easy for your compliance expert to find, such as “Compliance Trainees”.
    • If all of your users must complete the compliance training, you do not need to create this group.

For more detailed instructions, see our How Do I Create a New Group? article.

Creating a Security Role for Compliance Experts

Creating a security role will allow your compliance experts to search the ModStore for content, create a training campaign, and monitor users’ progress of the campaign. For more information on security roles, see our How to Use Security Roles article. 

Follow the steps below to create a security role:

  1. Log in to your KnowBe4 console and navigate to the Users tab.
  2. Click on the Security Roles subtab. 
  3. In the top-right corner of the page, click the +New Security Role button.
  4. Enter a descriptive name for the security role, such as “Compliance Experts”
  5. From the Groups drop-down menu, select the compliance expert group that you created in the section above.
  6. Click on Training and edit the training permissions of this security role.
    • For Training Campaigns, select Full Read/Write.
      • If you created a specific group for the users who need to complete this training, select that group from the Targeted Groups drop-down menu. 
      • If compliance training is for all of your users, keep the targeted groups set to All Users.
    • Keep the rest of the training permissions set to No Access.
  7. Click on the ModStore tab to edit the ModStore permissions for this security role.
    • For ModStore, select Read/Write.
    • For Library, select Read.
    • Keep the rest of the ModStore permissions set to No Access.
  8. When you are satisfied with your settings, click the Create Security Role button.

Now that your compliance experts have access to the necessary parts of the console, can use the article Finding and Using Compliance Plus Content as a guide.

articles.name: Grant ModStore Access
articles.title: Grant ModStore Access
articles.body:
Using security roles, you can allow any user to access the ModStore, browse for content, and add content to your account’s library. 

Note: These instructions are for current KnowBe4 customers and require access to our Security Roles feature. If you are not yet a customer, or if you don't have access to our Security Roles feature, please reach out to the KnowBe4 Sales Team.

Follow the steps below to create a ModStore security role:

  1. First, you must create a group that only includes the users who should have access to the ModStore. 
    • For detailed instructions, see our How Do I Create a New Group? Article.
  2. Once you have a group created, navigate to the Users tab.
  3. Click on the Security Roles subtab. 
  4. In the top-right corner of the page, click the +New Security Role button.
  5. Enter a descriptive name for the security role, such as “ModStore Access”.
  6. From the Groups drop-down menu, select the group that you created in step 1.

  7. Click on the ModStore tab to edit the ModStore permissions for this security role.
    • For ModStore, select Read/Write.
    • For Library, select Read.
    • Keep the rest of the ModStore permissions set to No Access.

  8. When you are satisfied with your settings, click the Create Security Role button.

Once this security role is created, the selected users can log in to the KnowBe4 console and access the ModStore tab, add content to your account’s library, and view content that has been added to the library.

articles.name: Automated Template Selection Overview
articles.title: Automated Template Selection Overview
articles.body:
Note: We’ve added advanced features to phishing templates! All accounts will be opted in to phishing template advanced features in 2025. For more information, see our Phishing Templates Advanced Features Guide.

When creating a phishing campaign, you have the option to use one of our Automated Template Selections to automatically select the templates used in your campaign. Automated template selections choose templates from topics you select and add variety to recurring phishing campaigns.

The three automated template selection options are AI-selected (Diamond-level customers only), Full Random, and Random. Click on the tabs below to learn more about each option.

AI-selected Phishing Templates

Diamond-level customers have the option to use AI-selected phishing templates. This feature uses data from KnowBe4’s Artificial Intelligence Defense Agents (AIDA) to select the most relevant and challenging template for each user. AI-selected templates are chosen based on a user’s training history, phishing events, and performance metrics, such as their Phish-prone percentage and Security Awareness Proficiency Assessment (SAPA) results. The more data AIDA has, the better it works, so we recommend using these templates for users who have some prior training or phishing history.

To avoid repetition in recurring campaigns, the AI-selected feature remembers the last five emails sent to each user and selects a different template for subsequent tests.

When using AI-selected templates, choose multiple topics to ensure you have a minimum of 20 templates. Providing a large number of templates for AIDA to choose from allows for more variety in your campaign. For best results, we recommend using 50 templates or more.

Full Random (Random Email to Each User)

The Full Random option automatically chooses different templates for each user by pulling from the selected topics. Users enrolled in the campaign will receive a variety of different emails. Using Full Random is a great way to prevent users from telling each other about an incoming phishing test. For an even more effective test, we recommend sending the emails over a period of time.

Note: To prevent users from getting the same phishing templates too often, the Full Random option skips the five most recently used phishing templates that were sent to each user.

Random (Same random email to all users)

The Random option will automatically choose one template from the selected topics. All users enrolled in this campaign will receive the same email. To help prevent users from telling each other about this phishing test, we recommend sending all emails when the campaign starts.

To avoid repetition in recurring campaigns, this feature remembers the last five emails sent and selects a different template for subsequent tests.

For more information about phishing campaigns, see our Creating and Managing Phishing Campaigns article.

articles.name: How to Export Scope Information
articles.title: How to Export Scope Information
articles.body:
You can use our scope exports feature to export information about your scopes from your KCM GRC account. Exporting your scope information may be beneficial during an audit, or if you need to keep a record of the status of your requirements, controls, and evidence at a particular point in time.

The exported information is referred to as a scope export. The scope export is a password-protected ZIP file that contains the following details about a scope: scoped requirements, controls, tasks, and task evidence. See the sections below to learn more.

Creating and Downloading a Scope Export

Account Administrators and Scope Administrators can create scope exports. However, Scope Administrators can only export their Allowed Scopes. To learn more about user roles and permissions, see our User Roles Guide.

Follow the steps below to create a new scope export:

  1. Navigate to the Scope Exports page. From the navigation panel, click Compliance > Scope Exports.
  2. Click the Create Export button. Then, on the Export a Scope page, add the information outlined below.
    1. Name: Add the name of the scope that you are exporting or another name that represents the information you're exporting. This name will show on the Scope Exports page.
    2. Description: Describe the scope or the information that you are exporting.
    3. Scope ID: Select the name of the scope that you would like to export.
    4. Choose Tasks to Export (optional): Click the All Tasks checkbox to export all of the tasks for the controls under this scope. If you'd only like to export tasks with a specific status, select the applicable checkbox or checkboxes.Alternatively, if you'd only like to export your scoped requirements and the controls that they are mapped to, deselect all of the checkboxes.
      Note: If tasks include task evidence, this evidence will also be included in the export. To learn more about viewing evidence in your export, see the Understanding the File Structure and Understanding the HTML File sections below.
    5. Password: Create a password for your export. Your password is case-sensitive. Please note that you will need to enter this password before you can unzip your export file.
  3. Click the Schedule Export button.

Once you see the Process Complete status in the Process Status column, you can download your export by clicking the download icon. Account Administrators and Scope Administrators can also delete exports from their platform by clicking the trash icon.

Note: Depending on the amount of data in your scope, it may take up to 15 minutes for your export to be available for download.

See the next section for details about the information available in your scope export.

Scope Export File

After you've downloaded your scope export, unzip the file and enter your password. See the following sections to learn about the contents of your scope export folder.

Understanding the File Structure

There are two primary parts of your scope export: The evidence files that have been submitted for your control tasks and the HTML file that outlines the requirements, controls, tasks, and evidence under your scope. See the details below to understand what is included in your export file.

  1. The name of your scope export folder. The folder name will contain your KCM GRC account name. You can see your account name under your Account Settings > Account Overview tab.
  2. Expand the documents folder to see a folder for each of the tasks that contain evidence in the form of a document (file).
    Note: Your documents folder will be empty if you did not include tasks in your export, or if you have exported tasks that haven't had evidence files submitted for them. For example, when creating your export, if you choose to export Past Due Tasks or Failed Tasks, it's likely that evidence has not been submitted for these tasks. View the index.html file to see details about these tasks. See the Understanding the HTML Page section below for more information.
  3. The task folder names include the task name and a task ID that is unique to your account. There will be a task folder for each task that contains evidence in the form of a document (file).
    • To view the tasks that contain evidence in the form of a link, open the index.html file. From the index.html file, you can also open and view the linked evidence. See the Understanding the HTML Page section below for details.
  4. The evidence file that has been submitted for the task.
  5. The css folder does not contain information about your scope, it only exists so that you can view the index.html file in your export. To ensure that your index.html file displays properly, do not edit or delete the files in this folder.
  6. Open the index.html file in your browser to view details about the requirements, controls, and tasks under your scope as a web page. See the next section to learn more about this file.

Understanding the HTML File

When you open the index.html file from your scope export folder, it displays as a webpage in your browser. The index.html file lists all of the requirements in your scope and includes the controls that the requirements are mapped to, when applicable. This file also provides details about the control tasks under this scope. See below for details about this page.

  1. The name of the scope that you have exported.
  2. The name of a requirement under this scope. This is known as a scoped requirement.
  3. The Requirement ID.
  4. The name of the control that is mapped to the requirement.
  5. The control description.
    Note: If more than one controls are mapped to the requirement, all controls will show under the requirement.
  6. User/Group Assigned: If there is a user or user group assigned to the control this information is displayed here.
  7. Manager: If there is an Approving Manager assigned to the control this information is displayed here.
  8. Click the plus button to see details about the tasks that have been created for this control, as outlined below.
    1. Name: The name of the task. The task may share the same name as the control that it was created for.
    2. Due Date: The date that the task is due.
    3. Status: The current status of the task. To learn more about the task statuses, see the Task Calendar section of our How to Use the My Dashboard Tab article.
    4. Stage: The current stage of the task. This is also known as the task's Approval Stage. To learn more about the task stages, see Approval Stage under our How to Monitor and Approve Tasks article.
    5. Evidence: The name that the User Assigned entered for the evidence when adding evidence to the task. If evidence has not been submitted for the task, "No Evidence" will display in this field instead.
      Tip: To view evidence from the index.html webpage, make sure that you have unzipped the scope export folder. Then, click the evidence name to open the link (URL) or document (file) that was submitted as evidence. Evidence links can only be opened from the index.html webpage. Evidence documents can be opened from the index.html webpage and the scope export folder. See the Understanding the File Structure section above for details about the scope export folder.
